direction.raw_text: - INT. HALLWAY - LIVING ROOM - DINING ROOM - DAY Living room. Georges is drinking tea and reading the newspaper. SILENCE. Suddenly, the DOORBELL RINGS. Georges, annoyed, puts down his newspaper, gets up, goes into the hallway and goes to the front door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who's there?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eva?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (a bit irritated) Yes. Georges, panicked, thinks for a few seconds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just a minute. He goes toward the bedroom door, locks it and puts the key in his pocket. He goes into the dining room, also closes the door leading to the bedroom. He comes back. He is about to go toward the front door, but remains motionless an instant, opens the door of the toilet that is located just nearby, flushes the toilet, closes the toilet door again and opens the front door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello. A brief kiss hello.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hello. What was going on?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was in the toilet. Sorry. He closes the front door behind Eva, indicates the direction of the living room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come in. Eva points to the bedroom with a questioning look. He shakes his head as if to play down the question, and indicates back in the direction of the living room, as if to say: "You understand, huh?". Eva is slightly irritated, but follows him into the living room. He closes the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why this unannounced visit? Where have you come from?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's going on with Mom?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing. What should be going on?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well... (gesture toward the
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't you want to sit down first? Eva wants to answer, but finally gives in and sits down. Georges does the same.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So why are you in Paris?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's going on with Mom? Why don't you answer the phone? After our last conversation, I left four messages on your answering machine. Why don't you call back?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry. I didn't listen to it. Forgive me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't you realize we're worried?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your worries are no use to me. Eva glares at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, don't get me wrong. I'm not criticizing you. I just don't have the time to deal with your worries, that's all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dad...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. Let's stop this conversation right there. I'm taking care of your mother. It's a full-time job. And I'm not saying that to complain, just to explain why I didn't answer your phone calls and why I don't want to have any pointless discussions on the subject. Your mother is just as could have been expected: bad the whole time. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She is turning more and more into a helpless child, and it's sad and humiliating, for her and for me. And she doesn't want to be seen in that state either. Even the last time you visited, she didn't want you to come. You two have your own life. Nothing wrong with that. But let us have our life too. Even though it's a lousy one. OK?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dad, what's the matter?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing's the matter; your visit caught me by surprise. And I'm annoyed that you show up here to check that everything's OK. Who do you think you are?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Eva is speechless.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... Then she gets up and makes to go to the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Stay here, will you! She stops short, looks at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (softly, but insistently) Please! She hesitates a moment, but winds up leaving the living room.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: WE HEAR HER PASS IN THE HALLWAY TO GO INTO THE BEDROOM AND HER VAIN ATTEMPT TO OPEN THE DOOR

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) Mom? ... Mom?? Georges remains seated, motionless, until she comes back. She seems upset by the situation, as one would expect.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell me, what's going on? Have you gone crazy?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please, sit down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't want to sit down. What's going on here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing's going on. I want to spare us all a pointless drama. I presume your mother is asleep. She mostly sleeps the whole day. And then she wakes up at night. If you really want to, we'll go and see her in a little while. Now, sit down. OK? They look at each other. Reluctantly, Eva heads toward her armchair and sits down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Then Georges goes on in a quiet voice:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We do our speech exercises every day, or we sing together. Most of the time, I wake up around 5. At that time, she's still awake. Then we change her incontinence pad. I rub cream on her to avoid sores. Then, around 7, I try to persuade her to eat and drink. Sometimes it works, sometimes not. Sometimes she tells me things from her childhood, then for hours she calls for help, and then an instant later she's giggling away to herself, or crying. Nothing of any of that is worth showing to anyone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Eva looks down. Finally, she says:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can't stop me from seeing her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No. They remain seated for a moment, finally Eva gets up. Georges follows her into the hallway. He unlocks the door and they enter the bedroom. The bright light from outside filters through the blinds.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Eva goes over to the bed, looks at Anne. Finally, she caresses her face, shyly and clumsily. Anne opens her eyes. Looks at her. No movement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's me, Mom. Anne emits a FURIOUS SOUND.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can I do something for you? Mom...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mom... Mom... Mom... Mom... Mom...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Georges has remained by the door. After a while, they both leave the bedroom, cross the hallway to come back in the living room. Georges closes the door. For an instant he puts a consoling hand on Eva's shoulder. Then he sits down. Eva, trying to compose herself, goes toward the window and looks outside. Suddenly she starts sobbing. After a while, Georges gets up and goes out of the room. Eva, vexed, blows her nose. Shortly after, Georges comes back. He has another teacup in his hand, puts it down beside his on the table and sits down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The tea isn't very hot any more. Eva turns toward him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But it does make you feel better. After a short PAUSE, Eva comes toward the table. Sits down. He fills her cup.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks. She takes the cup, drinks. Replaces it. Still can't bring herself to look at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was silly of me to lock the door. I'm sorry. You took me by surprise, that's all. I'm sorry. She nods her head, indicating she understands. Finally she looks at him:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's going to happen now?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (with a little ironic laugh) What's going to happen now? The nurse comes twice a week, and every two weeks Dr. Bertier and the hairdresser come. That's what you want to know, right? Things will go on as they have done up until now. They'll go from bad to worse. Things will go on, and then one day it will all be over. Brief PAUSE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can't go on like this, Dad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can't I? What do you suggest?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can't we have a serious talk, you and me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you call "a serious talk"? What do you want to suggest? Do you want to have Mom live with you? Do you want to pack her off to a care home? Do you? What do you want? Go on, talk to me "seriously"! Eva looks at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - INT. BEDROOM - DAY Georges is seated on the bed beside Anne, who is still bedridden.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (in a rush)... short... short dress... only I... only I... all long... it was... (with a small gesture to imitate a bell): ding... dong...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, it swung to and fro.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (still rushed) ... yes... to ... fro ... you... very serious... like that... (she imitates a serious countenance, continues in a low voice): like that... serious...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (unable to keep from laughing a little) Yes. I think I was pretty uptight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (smiling) yes... up... tight...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Anne puts her hand on Georges'.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... it was n...nice...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - INT. BATHROOM - HALLWAY - BEDROOM - DAY BATHROOM Georges is shaving. Suddenly we hear, coming from the bedroom,
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (loud) Help... Help... Help... Help... Help... Georges wipes his face and, to the sound of Anne's cries, crosses the hallway and enters the bedroom. Anne continues to cry out in a monotone to herself. Georges goes over to her bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (trying to calm her like a sick child) What is it?.. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you in pain?... What's the matter?... Is your pad full? He raises her blanket for an instant and sniffs, then replaces it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No... So what's hurting you? He sits down beside her on the bed. Takes her hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's all right... it's all right ... I'm here... everything's fine... we'll... Hold on, I'll tell you a story... but you must be quiet, I can't talk too loud, it wears me out... Here we go: when I was little... well, I wasn't as little as all that... it was toward the end of primary school, so I was about ten, Dad and Mom sent me to a holiday camp. They thought it would do me good to spend the summer with kids my own age... We were lodged in an old castle in the midst of a magnificent wooded landscape... I think it was in the Auvergne... I don't know... in any case it was the opposite of what I'd expected... We had to get up at 6 and go for a morning swim. Not far from the castle, there was a pond fed by an icy mountain stream. We entered it running, in a double file. You know, I was never very sporty. They had a program to keep us on the go all day, probably to nip any potential pubescent impulses in the bud ... But the worst thing was the food. The third day after our arrival, there was rice pudding for lunch. I hate rice pudding. We sat at long tables in a huge hall. I didn't want to eat the stuff and the housemaster said to me: You won't get up until you've cleared your plate. So after the meal everybody left the room, and I remained seated, in tears. I had made a secret pact with Mom. I was to send her a postcard every week. (MORE)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If I was pleased with the place I was to draw some flowers on it, or if not, some stars. She kept the card; it was covered all over in stars. After three hours, I was allowed to leave the table. I went up to my room, got into bed and had a fever of 42 degrees. It was diphtheria. They took me to the nearest hospital where I was put in an isolation ward, which meant that Mom, when she came to visit me, could only wave at me through a window. At some point I lost that postcard. It's a pity. Anne has become ever calmer during Georges' story. He still holds her hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Then Georges reaches across Anne's body to get hold of his pillow and presses it over her face. STIFLED SOUNDS from Anne. Everything that can still move in her body starts to move. Georges presses down heavily on the pillow, lies on it with his whole weight, for a long time, until all Anne's movements stop. Then he sits up, exhausted, and without removing the pillow from her face, remains seated beside her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - INT. HALLWAY - KITCHEN - DAY Hallway. The front door of the apartment is unlocked. Georges, in city clothes, enters with two big shopping bags full of cut flowers. He puts down the bags, takes off his coat, hangs it in the closet. The TELEPHONE RINGS. Georges takes the bags and carries them in the kitchen, puts them in the sink, fills it with water. He starts to cut the stems and put the flowers in the water. We watch him doing so for a while. Meanwhile, the TELEPHONE HAS STOPPED RINGING.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - INT. HALLWAY - DAY Georges has opened one of the sections of the large wall closet. He is looking for a specific dress. He takes some out, puts them back inside. One of the dresses slips off its hanger and falls to the floor. He picks it up, hangs it up again. He ends up finding the one he was looking for. He takes it out on its hanger. Closes the closet again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Looks at the dress. Then he lowers his arm a little and is about to leave the bedroom. He catches his feet in the dress. He just saves himself from tripping up by grabbing on to the wheelchair that is parked there. Exhausted, he flops down into it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - INT. HALLWAY - NIGHT With wide adhesive tape, Georges seals up the door frame of the bedroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - INT. KITCHEN - ADJOINING BEDROOM - HALLWAY - DAY Georges is seated at the kitchen table where he had breakfast with Anne in Scene 8, and writes a letter. PAUSES for reflection. GENTLE COOING OF PIGEONS, scarcely audible. Suddenly, Georges starts. At the far end of the long kitchen, beside the door between the kitchen units, a pigeon is walking. Georges stares at it. For a long time. Then he gets up slowly and, via the door located beside the kitchen table, he goes into the adjoining room. On the sofa there, he has set up his new bed. He takes the wool blanket from the bed and comes back into the kitchen, carefully approaches the pigeon that then runs off in alarm. Georges carefully opens up the blanket and finally throws it over the pigeon. But it manages to escape into the hallway. Georges follows it. This action is repeated several times. The pigeon is more and more panicky, starts to fly up, flutters about in all directions. Georges closes the light- well window to cut off its escape route. This lasts an exhausting amount of time, but he ends up capturing it. He cuddles it against him, rolled up in the blanket, leans against a wall, then holds it as if it were a baby.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - INT. ADJOINING ROOM - KITCHEN - NIGHT From the adjoining room, we see Georges seated at the kitchen table, writing. Finally we see what he is writing: ... you won't believe it. A pigeon came in, for the second time already, through the light well. This time I caught it. In fact it wasn't difficult at all. But I set it free again. I'm going to ...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - INT. ADJOINING ROOM - KITCHEN - HALLWAY - DAY 66. Georges is lying on his bed in the adjoining room, staring at the ceiling. O.S., we faintly hear the SOUND of running water, and from time to time the CLATTERING OF DISHES. After a while, Georges gets up and goes into the kitchen. He remains in the doorway and watches Anne who, doing the dishes, at first doesn't pay attention to him, then notices his presence and shoots him a quick glance, saying casually:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm almost done. Georges continues to look at her unwaveringly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can put your shoes on if you want. Georges looks at her an instant longer, passes beside her, goes into the hallway, sits down on a stool beside the closet and puts on his shoes. O.S. we hear Anne finishing her work. She comes out, hangs up her apron in the closet, disappears for a few moments into the bathroom. Meanwhile, Georges has got up, and looks in the bathroom where, clearly, Anne is tidying her hair and sprucing herself up. When she comes out again, he takes her coat from the closet and helps her put it on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thanks. They head for the front door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aren't you taking a coat? Georges thinks a few seconds, then takes his trench-coat from the hook and they leave the apartment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - INT. HALLWAY - BEDROOM - DINING ROOM - LIVING ROOM - DAY Four long shots: all the windows are open. The sun is shining. It is fairly bright. Hallway.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: SOUND OF A LOCK BEING OPENED

direction.raw_text: . Then the SOUND OF A LOCK BEING OPENED. Eva comes into the apartment. Remains a long time beside the door. Looks around her, ill at ease. Finally she hesitantly goes into the bedroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . Anne's twin bed isn't there any more. On Georges' bed lies only the bare mattress. Eva remains there a moment, then goes through the partition door into the dining room. There, everything is as usual. Eva continues into the living room. There too, everything is as usual. Eva stops by the piano stool. Looks out of the window, feeling at a loss. Then she heads toward the sofa and armchairs in the corner. On the table lie the remains of a snack. Eva looks at the table, turns again toward the open windows, through which we hear
direction.name: direction
